course.subject: ELEC
course.name: A System View of Communications: from Signals to Packets
course.description: Have you ever wondered what technologies go into your mobile phone or a WiFi hotspot?  Through hands on work with a simple but fully functional wireless communication system, you will understand the basic engineering tools used and tradeoffs encountered in the design of these systems.  This course is centered on weekly laboratories, each designed to introduce an important concept in the design of these systems.  The lab sessions are supported by two one-hour lectures and a tutorial that introduce the concepts for the next laboratory, as well as reviewing and expanding the concepts learned in the previous laboratory.
course.corequisites: (COMP 1021 OR COMP 1022P) AND (MATH 1003 OR MATH 1014 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH 1024)

reviews.author: Srijan
reviews.comment_content:
This is essentially a crash course into the systems communications aspect of computer science.
The course is divided into 3 parts:
1. Channel Transmission: This part focuses on how bits are transmitted through a channel and how errors can be minimised using channel coding, framing, equalizing etc.
2. Sharing of channels: This part focuses on how a channel/frequency is shared among multiple communications using different types of modulation and filtering
3. Layers of Communications: This part explores different layers of communication (Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Application etc.) and popular protocols associated with each.

All these ideas are reinforced during labs where these principles are applied by coding a physical transmitter using MATLAB. The content is not too difficult as long as you pay attention in labs and tutorials
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Ross is really good. He is passionate about the subject and thus teaches accordingly. Most content is explained pretty well and doubts are resolved promptly.
Cupid is an amazing TA as well. She takes time to explain every type of question step by step and is always available for doubts.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading weightage:
Lab - 25%
       - Checkpoints - 10%
       - Post-lab quiz - 15%
Homework - 10%
Midterm - 25%
Final - 40%
reviews.comment_workload:
Decent for a 4cr course.
There are only 3 100pt Homeworks throughout the course that you have weeks to complete and dont take more than a few hours.
There is a 3-hour lab every week along with a post-lab quiz. The labwork and quiz finish in like an hour and then you can leave. The quiz is a 5-minute 5pt open book canvas quiz which basically covers questions from the previous tutorial.
Apart from that the only workload is actually studying for the exams which is fine as long as you attend and focus in each class and tutorial.

reviews.author: mark_
reviews.title: Good course overall with interesting content and nice grading. This review would have given a perfect score! But...
reviews.comment_content:
The content is quite approachable.

- Signals and effects of the channel
- LTI systems
- Transmitting data
- Noise
- Error correcting codes
- Time domain / frequency domain analysis
- Signal transmission, frequency division multiplexing
- Networking (OSI model)

To be honest it was quite an interesting course. I would recommend even aspiring CS majors to take this.
reviews.comment_teaching:
This section *would* have been given an A if it were not for what happened to a friend of mine after exams finished.

Let's get through the positives first. Professor Zhang is nice and explains concepts clearly. He is open to questions after class and via. email. The IA, Cupid CHOW, is also very nice and organises most things for the course. During tutorials, she explains questions step by step to make sure you understand. She is also very reachable by email and is open to help. (Only concern is she types everything in Comic Sans for some reason, including the exams. :P)

However...

Near the end of semester, my friend ended up getting a 0 for their project code as it was unable to be run. Why? They tested their code thoroughly, and it ran without issue.

It was because they downloaded an older version of the project template the teaching team released a day before the project briefing. The teaching team had actually reuploaded a new version of the project template with a completely different structure, but did not tell anyone after doing so! My friend was essentially working on an older version of the project, so of course their code failed when it was run by the teaching team.

This level of irresponsibility baffles me, especially because this is for a course component worth 20% of the final grade. There was no way they could have known about the change without downloading the project again.

Nothing personal against the teaching team; I think they are great people... but I cannot let something like this slide.

UPDATE: My friend got their marks back after using a whole evening on investigating and writing an appeal. I've given the teaching a B since the instructors handled it reasonably and quickly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading policy:

Lab [Total: 15%]:
    Lab check-off points [5%]
    Post-lab quiz [10%]
Online homework [10%]
Midterm [25%]
Project [20%]
Final [30%]

---
LABS

Lab check-points are easy. Just read the labs and do them, and you can get the check points without much problem.

The post-lab quizzes on the other hand are quite difficult and stressful. You need to really revise the content and pay attention in the tutorial to get a good score on them. They are all 5 minutes long with 5 MCQ or text entry questions.

There are 7 labs in total, 6 of which are graded. The first one is a trial lab you get you familiar with the procedures. You must attend at least 5 labs to pass.

Mean (check-off points): 21.67/24
Mean (post-lab quiz): 16.29/29

---
HOMEWORK

The homework is not too bad. Just read the lecture slides and you should be able to do them. But, don't do them the day they're due - many of my classmates ended up not finishing on time due to them leaving it till the last minute.

There are 3 homeworks in total, and combined, they are worth 120 marks. Depending on how well you understand the content, they can take between an hour and a few days to do.

Mean: 99.83/120

---
PROJECT

The project this semester was creating a transmitter and receiver to reliably transmit a sequence of bits over a fairly noisy channel while conserving as much power as possible. Due to it being an online semester, you do the project in Matlab and transmit over a virtual channel.

But, I think just the content from the course is not enough to get full marks. Accounting for variations in the given channel (everyone's channel has different noise), I think I had one of the lowest power usages of anyone I knew, but I still lost a point for the power consumption part. In fact, nobody in my session got full marks for power consumption.

In addition to writing the Matlab code, you have to write a report detailing any experiments you did and how you got the result that you did.

(Update: I asked about the grading for this part. They create a sub-optimal reference solution using a simple noise reduction technique and a greedy search. They then compare your solution to theirs, and only if your solution uses less power will you get full marks.)

The report is worth 8 marks, your code is worth 5, and the power consumption is worth 7. It is overall worth 20 marks.

Mean: 10.6/20 SD 4.5

---
EXAMS

The exams are like a combination of the post-lab quizzes and the homeworks. It starts with a few homework style short answer questions. Then, there are a bunch of multiple-choice/text entry questions, not unlike what you would find in the post-lab quiz.

The long questions are similar in difficulty to the homework, but of course there is a time limit.

The rest of the questions are similar to the post-lab quizzes. However you get 2 minutes per question compared to the 1 minute per question you get in the actual post-lab quizzes. So, you have more time to do them.

Overall, I think the exams are not too bad. They are fairly doable if you revise the content and practice. (They are open-book, open-calculator this semester).

Mean (midterm): 27/36 SD 6
Mean (final): 31.3/50 SD 9.4

---
OVERALL

The overall mean is 66.58.

This semester, one can get A+ with 93% and A- with 79% (exact boundaries unknown). So, it seems the A range is fairly wide.
reviews.comment_workload:
Every week, you must attend the lab and do the post-lab quiz. This will eat up about 1-2 hours of your time each week.

You will also have to do the homeworks.

Near the end of semester, you will also have to do the project. For me, this took about 15 hours of work in total, including the report.

Apart from that, there is not much else you have to do. I think the workload is fair for a 4-credit course.

reviews.author: Wiktor
reviews.comment_content:
This course is a great introduction to communication systems, it covers everything from basic bit signals to how the Internet works.
Course content:
- Encoding information with bits
- Continuous vs discrete-time waveforms
- Discrete-time bit waveforms
- Discrete-time channel
- Effects of the channel
- Linear Time-Invariant Systems
- Modelling the channel
- Decoding bits
- Asynchronous serial communication
- Intersymbol interference
- Eye diagrams
- Recursive channel model
- Equaliser
- Noise
- Gaussian Probability Density Function of noise
- Q-function and the Bit Error Rate
- Channel coding
- Fourier Series Expansion
- Filter types
- Time-frequency analysis
- Source coding/data compression
- Signal transmission
- Duplex communications
- Channel sharing or multiplexing/demultiplexing
- Modulation and demodulation
- Hierarchy of networks
- Network structure and layering
- Multiple access protocols
- Forwarding and routing
reviews.comment_teaching: In my opinion, professor ZHANG, Jun is very bad at explaining the course content, he rarely read the chat and his explanations were extremely confusing.
reviews.comment_grading:
Labs 15%:
- Check-off points 10% - mandatory 5 labs out of 7 to pass the course
- Post-lab quiz 5%
Homework 10%
- 3 sets of exercises on Canvas
Midterm 25%
Final 30%
Project 20%
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is rather light, although you should prepare for the post-lab quizzes very thoroughly - there are a lot of questions that require you to be fluent in the course material up to that point. The homework is somewhat based on the material covered in the lectures but most often than not, you will have to discuss the problems with your classmates to get an idea of what to do. The project is fun, it is just graded tinkering in MATLAB.

reviews.comment_grading:
yoinking framework from others again
Lab (30%)
Homework (10%)
Midterm Exam (30%)
Final Project (30%)

First, and most importantly, you will need to have some basic idea for programming, not any language, just the concepts like (if, for loop, while, array and such), because MATLAB would be used throughout the entire course.

Lab is just whatever, copy the instruction, and if you are on pace with the normal lecture flow, you would be able to answer the logic behind it. Also you will be paired up with another guy (It was on campus back then, not online teaching)
The post-lab quiz is also just really basic stuff, as long as you read the powerpoint, you will be fine.

Homework you can find formula from powerpoint, or ask other people.

Midterm is also just testing the concepts behind how packaging and unpacking data.

For my semester, basically from L19 and onward, all those stuff are not tested (except in homework, which im sure you can find a way to do it), so i just skipped the last 5 lectures.

Final project could cause some issue though, we were asked to design a simple voice recognition program to differentiate between 2 words, and simulating an entire sentence being trasmitted, before retreiving the sentence back. Also, theres a written report, but that is basically free mark.

It is hard not because of the programming, but because of how inconsistent the entire thing is, my program worked completely fine on my end, but since the demo is performed on campus, my voice recognition program was not working properly.

Heres what i got:
Lab: all lab checks done, post lab quiz either full mark or above mean.
Midterm: 32/40 (mean 26.91)
Homework: no mean given but i think i was just about mean
Final project:
MATLAB code: 4/4
Written report: 6/6
Project demo: 17/20 (mean 12.47)

Grade: A+

reviews.author: DrainGang
reviews.title: Decent, but exams are hard.
reviews.comment_content:
Basic introduction to communications, for details, refer to other guides, the content is actually quite interesting, even for a CPEG student like me.

The materials for the course are quite simple, but be aware that the difficulty spikes during the last 1/3 of the course, and the last 2-3 lectures have a lot of memorization involved, would be challenging to study (unless you still have online exams by the time you read this)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lectures: quite boring, just repeating what is on the powerpoint, no attendance required so you can just look at them yourself at your own pace.

Tutorials: no attendance required, but you MUST go (even if the mainland TAs have an extremely heavy accent that makes it almost impossible to listen to) because the questions explained in the tutorial will be THE SAME as the ones in the post-lab quiz, if you want to do good in the post-lab quizzes, you have to attend the tutorials. The tutorials also go over the lab, which could help you out when you are stuck.

Labs: All instructions are on CANVAS, you just follow them to finish the lab, the lab check-points are also on CANVAS, so even if you are stuck on matlab it really doesn't matter.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% check points: basic MATLAB programming

15% Post-Lab Quiz: has NO RELATION TO LECTURE MATERIALS, make sure you attend and study the tutorial materials and you would do alright.

10% Homework: 3 homeworks, all are quite easy as well, averages are high and you should start working on homework 2 as soon as possible because homework 3 is released RIGHT AFTER homework 2.

25% Midterm: Covers the first 10 lectures, 2 halves, first half MC/fill in the blanks/True or False, second half text-entry questions. The first half is quite simple, if you studied you would know the answers, the second half is quite difficult as the calculations are much more difficult compared to what you will see in the lectures and tutorials, the questions are time consuming as well, averages are low (32.6/60)

40% Final: Covers the entire course, the same thing as midterm, challenging calculations, even more time consuming questions, make sure you finish them as quickly as possible. ALSO: inputting equations in CANVAS is a major annoyance because you CANNOT copy and paste what you have typed, you MUST input every equation by hand or the website WILL CRASH.

Final grade: 8% above mean overall, B+, acceptable grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite light for a 4-credit course.

Labs take at most 1-2 hours per week, and preparing for the post-lab quiz takes half an hour or so, so overall you don't have to spend that much time on this course.

As for the homework, they are quite short and easy, so again does not take that much time, but since they are easy you may make careless mistakes, so double check your answers with a friend to make sure you did the questions right.

Exams: doesn't take very long to understand the concepts, but as I have said, calculations are difficult in the exam and there is only ONE past paper given, so make you do look at the homework and the 1 past paper otherwise you have no way of studying for the exams.

reviews.comment_teaching:
There are reviews and introductions at the beginning of each lecture, and reviews at the end of each lecture.  Tutorials provide more examples and introduce the coming lab. Meanwhile, labs provide practices to help to consolidate knowledge.

Time for lectures is ample for its contents. Prof Murch is passionate and he always asks students to raise questions if any. Apart from that, he repeats important ideas so as to make sure everybody understands.

TA Cupid holds tutorials and labs. Even though different students have asked on the same question and she has answered before, she would still explain them patiently.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading policy:
- 7 Labs (MATLAB simulations) 30%
-- Lab Check-off Points (15%)
-- Post-lab Quiz (15%)
- 3 HWs 10%
- Midterm Exam (30%)
- Final Project (30%)

Labs:
MATLAB is used for simulations in the labs. MATLAB codes are given and minor additions and amendments are needed. Completed codes are not needed for submission but will be useful in the final project. Lab instructions and lab check-off points are released around a week before the scheduled lab time. Both check-off points and quizzes cover the content of surrounding lectures and that lab.

Attendance of labs is not mandatory, but lab check-off points (5 questions per lab) have to be completed before the post-lab quizzes (5 questions per lab), and the quizzes are only available in the last 10 minutes of the scheduled lab time.

Midterm Exam:
Closed book
MCs (20 mins) (16% of course grade)
Short Questions (30 mins) (14% of course grade)

Final Project:
5 short questions (In which 3 are like lab - modifying MATLAB codes, 2 requires more of MATLAB programming)
5 questions on decoding data and addresses at the receiver (write MATLAB codes from scratch to decode data streams in different scenarios (including noise, channel coding, intersymbol interference))
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite low for most of the time. However, towards the end of the semester, the workload starts to rise. HW3 is released right after HW2. The final project wouldn't be that hard once you understand the course content thoroughly.

reviews.author: sheepy
reviews.comment_content:
See others for the detail.

reviews.author: Toson
reviews.comment_content:
This is essentially a crash course into the systems communications aspect of computer science.
The course is divided into 3 parts:
1. Channel Transmission: This part focuses on how bits are transmitted through a channel and how errors can be minimised using channel coding, framing, equalizing etc.
2. Sharing of channels: This part focuses on how a channel/frequency is shared among multiple communications using different types of modulation and filtering
3. Layers of Communications: This part explores different layers of communication (Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Application etc.) and popular protocols associated with each.

All these ideas are reinforced during labs where these principles are applied by coding a physical transmitter using MATLAB. The content is not too difficult as long as you pay attention in labs and tutorials
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor can explain the hard topic and make it much easier to understand than reading the lecture material yourself. This is a hard course. The detail of BJT model and MOSFET is very frustrating when it comes to calculation. Therefore, remember to attend the last few lecture and review the course with professor before midterm and final exam.

TAs are welling to answer most of the questions when you ask them. If you struggling with the homework, try your best and ask the TAs after the tutorial. They will help you a lot.
reviews.comment_grading: A hard course. But always someone can get almost full marks in midterm and final exam. Both of them are open book, but only printed material. It is a good chance to review. Remember to pay attention on the homework. Some of them are similar to exam questions.
reviews.comment_workload: Need quiz after lab every time. quiz is quite hard, all lab can get a full mark

reviews.title: ELEC 1200
reviews.comment_content: It is about signals.

reviews.comment_grading:
This course is graded based upon homework, lab quizzes, one exam and a final project.

The final project is worth 30%, so you should consider spending some time on it.

The exam only covers content until midterm, and this content is fairly easy compared to the content after the exam.

The grading is lenient in my opinion as I got an A+.

The topics discussed is quite interesting if you want to find out how signal is transmitted between devices. However, the difficulty of lectures drastically increases starting from L10 where you will start to do some math about error rate and signal multiplexing modem. It's important to do past papers and ask Cupid for unclear concepts if you want a good grade.

Total 8 labs. For each lab, there're 4 MATLAB checkpoints and a 5min open-book post-lab quiz. But the first lab doesn't count towards final grade. Usually lab can be finished in an hour despite the time reserved on the timetable.

Total 3 pieces of homework. The first one is due before midterm while the last 2 is due about two weeks before final exam period.

Final project consists of two parts, both parts requires MATLAB coding. First part is about distinguishing the sound between two simple single-syllable English word. Second part is about signal transmission through an unknown channel (with noise and delay).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lectures: Prof. Ross is good, he can answer your question clearly if you got one and some stay behind to ask him questions.

Tutorials: It depends on the tutor as TAs will take turns to give tutorials. Most explains the topics with examples questions. You have to study the tutorial notes in order to have good post-lab quizzes. Cupid is nice and always available for questions at any time in the tutorial and during office hours.

reviews.comment_workload:
Decent for a 4 credit course.

There are only 3 pieces of homework throughout the semester and each of them has more than 1 week to finish. But be aware that the third homework is released right after the second homework. So mind the due day of the homework.

Each lab usually takes around 1 to 1.5 hours to finish. You can ask TAs for hints if you are stuck on a certain task.

Midterm is a little bit intense. It's reasonable as long as you study for all calculations in tutorial and homework. Remember to do past papers to familiarize yourself with the questions because some of them are not that intuitive.

For the final project, you can use the code (including the precompiled .p file) you used in labs. It is not that hard if you understand the concepts thoroughly. The demonstration is carried out in the room you have labs with a pre-assigned time slot. It is quite difficult to get full marks in the first part of the project as you can't test with the mic they use beforehand.

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload in this semester is quite heavy as it is a 4-credit course.

reviews.author: isonngky
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers basically the fundamental background knowledge of signals. It helps you develop a step-by-step understanding of the system communication through lectures and lab sessions.

There are in total 8 lab sessions using MATLAB to learn and try on signals/messages transmission, with each session covering a different focus taught on previous lectures.

All the materials taught in this course are quite easy to follow. It does not require a strong mathematical background like other engineering courses, but the understanding of concepts behind it. In another word, you don't have to know why the formulae work, just to understand the reason we use them and then apply them.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I would suggest f2f instead of online. Prof always spends time on lessons answering students' questions. All concepts taught are clearly explained with examples. He is very nice so don't hesitate to ask if you don't understand some of the concepts.

The TAs are helpful too. The tutorials are very important as it covers all the concepts taught on the previous topics and some hints for the upcoming lab session. Though they are not going to teach you directly how you should do.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think this course gives a fairly good grade.
Lab+quiz: 30%
Homework: 10%
Midterm: 30%
Project: 30%
Not hard for a B range. If you perform well in midterm then basically an A range. Given that your assignments and quizzes are not doing bad of course.
I performed well in the midterm but not in the project. Turns out still in the A range so the midterm is quite important.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is on the average level.
This is a 4-cred course so it does have a certain workload.
About a lab session and two lectures a week. A following post-lab quiz after every lab session. In total 3 online assignments. A midterm and a final project. That's all.
If you really pay attention during lectures and tutorials, you don't need much extra time for revision. The post-lab quizzes are very straightforward, if you are doing all the stuff in the lab on your own then you shouldn't find them hard.
The midterm is quite hard tbh, so you need to have a full understanding of the topics covered.

reviews.comment_grading: I think the grading is very good. I just only get the mean in my post-lab quiz, mid-term exam and homework. I get the full mark on the project. Finally, I get A grade in this course.

reviews.comment_content:
The content was easy to understand most of the time, except after signal modulation. (Week 9, L16; Read other reviews for the course outline, not going to post again). The parts for modulating signals are very math-based, but high school math is enough to tackle all that. Used a lot of trigonometries and continuous functions. Dijkstra algorithm in the latter part of the course might be tricky for some.

In terms of coding, MATLAB is used, some efforts need to be paid. It wasn't something super complex, and coding involves correcting basic mistakes, manipulating arithmetic and arrays, making histograms and charts. More complex items would be modifying codes inside pre-written models.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Murch and Cupid were very friendly. Lectures weren't boring, he answered questions swiftly and explained everything clearly. PPTs were easy to navigate and had a maximum of 30 pages per lecture.

Tutorials were a great compliment to the lectures and usually gives a kickstart towards the labs. You will have plenty of time to complete labs during

reviews.comment_workload:
A typical 4-credit course workload.

Lab checkpoints were easy to do, some were too easy that they could be completed with common sense, and not fair to hardworking students as no reports were required and many can guess the checkpoints without doing the coding. Post lab quiz opens at the last 10 mins and gives 5 mins to complete, be sure to listen to hints during tutorials and labs. 5 questions, cannot return to previous questions, have some calculations to do, so they require some familiarity with the lectures.

Make sure you do the math quick and have clear concepts in midterm exam. In this way, going at least mean+sd can be easy. It sucked when you cannot return to the previous question and have time pressure on you.

Not a big deal for the assignments, referring to course notes alone can get you most of the answers. Some further understanding and intelligence required to get the rest. Time was more than enough to complete them.

Final exam was substituted by a Project this semester, should be more than enough time to do given that there's a month for completion. It was in 2 parts, each with 5 3-point blocks. Pay some efforts into it and it's easy to secure the first 15 points. It was more challenging than labs as we had to start from scratch for many parts, even when we were allowed to reuse some lab codes. Second part was interesting and demanding to work out.

The 3 homeworks take a few hours to complete. Really pay attention when you do them or else you'll lose marks.

The weekly labs were just MATLAB tasks and they're basically optional. If you understand the course content, you won't need to do them to get the post-lab quiz and lab checkpoints.

Make sure you study for the midterm. The mean was pretty low, so it was pretty hard.

reviews.author: Vegetable
reviews.title: AWESOME PROF AND IA!
reviews.comment_content: Cover some basic concepts of communication. Each of them is  not hard, but the prof. might go through them very quick, especially after mid-term. If you are willing to spend about 1 hour per week after class, you can handle them easily.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. MURCH is very passionate on teaching, and willing to answer every question you have. The English accent of him is very comfortable to follow, and he is also very handsome!

SPECIAL CREDIT to Ms. Cupid Chow!!!! She is the best IA I have ever met in my student life! She can anwer every question as long as it is legal in a very short time. The expected time of her email reply is in 10 min!
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 10%
Lab Check & Post Lab Quiz 30%
Mid-term 30%
Final Project 30%

I got ~95%, should be A+
reviews.comment_workload: Very low. Take some time to prepare for the post lab quiz, and everthing will be fine. There are three homeworks in total, each taking about 2 hours. Remember to do the final project as soon as possible after it is released, which will significantly relieve your finalp pressure!

reviews.author: XIA YUNLEI
reviews.title: Be careful of your quiz
reviews.comment_content:
From this course, you can learn the following things.
1. Examine a voice communication system to identify the practical context of key theoretical concepts in ECE.
2. Identify typical problems and tradeoffs encountered in electronic and computer engineering systems.
3. Analyze simple approaches to address a range of problems and tradeoffs.
4. Use software tools, such as MATLAB, to investigate potential solutions to problems and tradeoffs in order to validate an analysis, and to handle cases not amenable to simple analysis.
5. Work in a cooperative setting on real hardware where the simplifying assumptions used in the theoretical analysis may be violated, and assess the benefits and limitations of such analysis.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lecture was boring, and you can learn by yourself with the ppt.
However, the tutorial was quite useful, you can learn many practical problem solving approach and the TA was nice.
The lab was quite easy too, you just need read the materials before the lab and TA will help you with all your problems.But be careful of the quiz, it may be very difficult.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading policy is Lab Check-off Points 10%; Quiz 15%; Homework 10%; Midterm 25%; Final 40%.
As a result, if you performed well in your daily study and understand most of the contents, you'll get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload of this course was not so heavy.
In fact, you can just go to the tutorial and the lab, the lecture is not necessary, the quiz should be prepared well and the exam will be much easier than the quiz. There were only three homeworks with the basic questions and you may find out later that some exam questions are the same as the homeworks'.

reviews.author: aNShk
reviews.comment_content: Content is interesting. It covers topics like linear time invariant system, loseless and lossy compression and network etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Mow teaches well, he manages to cover a set of slides in a limited time period. Sometimes, he will talk faster near the end of lesson as he need to finish the topic off but you can always watch the lecture video if you miss something.
The tutorial section is very informative and just ask the TA whatever questions you have, they explain well.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab 25%
Homework 10%
Midterm 25%
Final 40%
reviews.comment_workload:
Only attendance in lab is needed and there are 4 homeworks. The lab quiz are pretty easy but make sure to revise the tutorial notes and what you did in that lab.
For the homeworks, some questions need more thinking and are not that straight forward but the lecture slides definitely helps.

reviews.author: 樹大有枯枝
reviews.comment_content:
Three parts:
Signal transmission in time domain: bit sequences, sampling, protocols, step response and recursive models, equalizer, noise, error correction codes. Covered before mid-term.

Signal transmission in frequency domain: most abstract part of the course. sinusoidal waves, amplitude spectrum, frequency response, time-frequency analysis, modulation, demodulation, filters.

Networks: internet, the functions and protocols of each layer in OSI model
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Murch explains the abstract concepts quite clearly to prepare you for the much harder assignments and exams.

Cupid knows the content very well (probably she prepared all the lecture notes, assignments and lab contents) and is very nice.  She goes through the paper with you all over in paper-checking and is very willing to answer your questions any time you come to her office (in Cantonese, if you wish).

The lab assistants are quite helpful and friendly and sometimes can also answer your questions regarding the concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab (25%): completion (10%), lab quizzes (15%)
Homework (10%)
Mid-term (25%)
Final (40%)
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is light, only 3 assignments which are probably ok if you check answers with your friends.

The labs last 3 hours starting at 9, but can be completed within an hour (you just need to change a few lines of code in each of the 4 tasks, and the changes are explained clearly in the tutorials), so I've always wondered why they can't start later.
The lab quizzes are nearly identical to the questions in the tutorials.
(The answers to the quizzes are not released, but you can check them with Cupid)

The mid-terms and exams are quite similar to the assignments and the review questions. No calculators, get ready to memorize sin cos values of common angles and product-to-sum formulas.

reviews.comment_content:
Basically it is introducing some basic ideas about how 'wireless communication work'. It goes from

1. how to represent data using 0 and 1
2. how to convert the 010001001... sequence into wave form (carrier of the data)
(Transmit the wave form in the transmission channel [Transmitter<-------------->Destination]
3. *modelling* the response of the transmission channel (air) i.e. input vs output
4. How to perform data correction when the wave form is modified by noise during transmission?
5. how to do modulation i.e. transmit different message at same time using same channel (air) without crush
6. some network concepts


It is fun to know how transmission work!!! It gives you ideas about how engineer viewing the world! But for deeper understanding, then you need to go to higher level course.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor and TA are helpful in answering the questions. I email them once I got some points unclear and get fast reply.
reviews.comment_grading:
I dun have many statistics. Below is a reference:

me: total ~95%
=>A+
reviews.comment_workload: Have lab every week which is quite tired, through it is not hard. It is a motivation for you to start study the course earlier. Therefore, you dun have to deadline fight before the exam.

reviews.author: Never Social
reviews.title: Well designed course, extremely low workload (for 4cr course)
reviews.comment_content:
Please refer to other posts for the generals.

"ELEC majors told me this course is a good foundation for advanced courses." (Murch, 2019)

Assignments * 3
Nothing hard. Just collaborate with someone to ensure accuracy.
Weekly labs/ post-lab quiz
The difficulty of the lab over time is quadratic, which peaked at the middle. Group mate who came in prepared makes lives easy.
You better have someone who's decent in reading codes or else its hell.
Post-lab quiz almost directly correspond to tutorial materials, easy.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lectures
Ross is charismatic, it is almost certain that there existed a queue of confused students post-class yet he answered them one by one..

Tutorials
Cupid talks to herself in tutorials cuz its 0900 and no one is awake but she still give good explanation in tutorials/ labs

Labs
Lab assistants are responsive. Sadly I can't go deeper as my group barely need any help.
Computers are faster then human my ass.
👌👌 10 minute to load fn Matlab
👌👌 5 minute to load Chrome
👌👌 2.5 to download lab code
👌👌 2.5 to load lab code
👌👌 2019 gottem
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab: 25% * 24.63/25
Homework: 10% * 298/300
MT: 25% * 49/50
Final: 40% * 88.75/100 (haha was w0ke 22hrs when I started zzZ)

Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
LMFAO. Almost non-existant.

Weekly time allocation:
2hrs lectures, 1hr tutorial (I skipped in the second half)
1-3hr lab (~45minutes if fully prepped)

Literally took 3hrs to prep final
Literally took 45+hrs to prep COMP2711, another 4cr course.

Take this course lol SENG yr1s.

reviews.author: CS水泡
reviews.comment_content:
A basic introduction of signal and communication from the low level(bits, signal processing, error detection and correction) to higher network infrastructure(network layers, routing, protocols)

Just an overview of digital communication on multiple levels, nothing in depth but it does cover a lot of content. Easy grades if you know a little about networking, bits, etc but it is not necessary.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is good at teaching the content. As long as you attend the lectures and pay some attention, the content itself isn't difficult. His response to questions is also very helpful for the understanding of the content.

There are two parts of teaching. The lectures talk about the theoretical aspects with respect to communication, whereas the tutorials and lab session let you experiment with implementation using MATLAB. They cover different aspects and tutorials are advised to attend

Tutorials are very important and Cupid teaches well.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab: 25%
    lab tasks: 10%
    lab quizzes: 15% (5 minutes, 5 questions)
Homework: 10%
Midterm: 25%
Final: 40%

*It will be an auto-fail if you skip the labs for more than twice.

Midterm:
    Average: 36.7/52
    SD: 8.9
Final:
    Average: 75.85/100
    SD: 17.1

The labs and homework are just finishing checklists, easy to get near full mark. Midterm may seem to have a strict time constraint but it is rather manageable since they don't give you time-consuming questions.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is relatively light considering the lectures don't take attendance and you can usually finish the labs within half of the 3 hours given. The tutorials are useful to speed up your labs and they provide near identical example questions for the lab quizzes.

Besides regular class and labs, there is a midterm, a final and three homework. Not much memorization is needed for the written exams as they are mainly testing your concepts. Lab quizzes are open notes, meaning no phones but you can use your laptop to review the lecture and tutorial notes.

reviews.author: nussun54
reviews.title: A System View of Communications: from Signals to Packets
reviews.comment_content:
1. Examine a voice communication system to identify the practical context of key theoretical concepts in ECE.
2. Identify typical problems and tradeoffs encountered in electronic and computer engineering systems.
3. Analyze simple approaches to address a range of problems and tradeoffs.
4. Use software tools, such as MATLAB, to investigate potential solutions to problems and tradeoffs in order to validate an analysis, and to handle cases not amenable to simple analysis.
5. Work in a cooperative setting on real hardware where the simplifying assumptions used in theoretical analysis may be violated, and assess the benefits and limitations of such analysis.

The majority of this course focuses on how we transmit signals from a machine to machine basis, then the last quarter focuses on a bigger picture, on how the entirety of networks, internet etc. works and functions although this part was very brief and rather rushed.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Ben Letaief was good, thought he really emphasised the overall uses and importance of signal transmission in real life applications rather than content that might be examined. For those who are more grade-focused rather than just interested in the topic might struggle with his lectures as he sometimes goes through some important content rather quickly but focuses on "non-exam" content e.g. real life applications a lot more than needed, wasting a lot of the 50 minute lecture time. Really important to understand the lectures from the start to ensure you know what is happening later on as it is very much linked together. Some might struggle at the start with the content if there isn't a good background of signals. If there is any confusion, ask Cupid, she was really helpful and willing to solve any problems that you may have. She also teaches the tutorials which are important for lab work and some review of lecture content. Lecture videos are also provided.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab (25%)
     - Check-off Points (10%)
     - Post-lab quiz (15%)
Homework (10%)
Midterm Exam (25%)
Final Exam (40%)

I did slightly above average in midterm. Many people got very high grades I thought I was gonna get an average grade in the end. But the final exam was much easier than expected and I did a lot better (97.5%). The 10% check-off point from labs is essentially attendance but the 15% post lab quiz probably requires more attention than I initially thought. I did struggle through the initial quizzes and it is good to review some notes before taking the quiz as there is also a time limit (5 minutes). I ended up with an A+ which I didn't expect until I did my final exam. I thought grading was fair.

Midterms: Mean = 37.5/50; S.D. = 7.8
Finals: Mean = 74.8/100; S.D. = 18.1
reviews.comment_workload:
2 hour of lecture time per week
1 hour of tutorial per week
"3 hours" lab work per week

Lecture is rather short so it is key that you listen carefully.
Tutorial is extremely key to the lab (especially if you do not understand) as Cupid essentially goes through how to conduct the lab.
3 hours of lab time is given but could be finished in 30-45 mins if capable in MATLAB (The first lab is teaching you how to use MATLAB). I suggest spending some time to reading notes after your lab work to prepare for the 5 minute quiz. Overall should not exceed 1 hour and  30 minutes maximum. (I always finished the lab work and quiz within an hour as I also had a decent lab partner)
3 homework which were fair in length, not extremely hard.

reviews.author: kus
reviews.title: Quite good course if you are willing to work
reviews.comment_content:
Weekly Class Schedule:

L01: Course Introduction
L02: Signals
L03: Real World Channels
L04: Transmitting Data
L05: Intersymbol Interference and Eye Diagram
L06: Feedback Model of the Channel
L07: Channel Equalization
L08: Noise
L09: Noise
L10: Error Correcting Codes
L11: Error Correcting Codes
---------------------------------------------------------
MID-TERM
---------------------------------------------------------
L12: The Frequency Domain
L13: Discrete Fourier Transform/Frequency Response
L14: Signal Transmission – Modulation
L15: Signal Transmission – Demodulation
L16: I-Q Modulation
L17: Lossy Source Coding
L18: Introduction to Networking
-circuit switching v.s. packet switching
-layering
L19: Link Layer
-Multiple Access Protocol (MAC)
-Random Access Protocol (RAC)
*ALOHA
L20: Network Layer
-Internet Protocol (IP)
L21: Network Layer II
-Routing (Dijkstra’s algorithm)

-timeout
L23: Application Layer
L24:  Course Review
---------------------------------------------------------
reviews.comment_teaching:
Good prof. , willing to answer your question
while the TA in lab section depends on your luck
reviews.comment_grading: Be aware of the pro-lab quiz, although it's very easy, it only provides you with 5mins to ans 5 questions without correction. Sometime it is hard to finished properly, especially if you're a time-sensitive person.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 Asginments
1 Mid-term
1 Final
Lab section every week and a pro-lab quiz
------------------------------------------------------------
It's a 4 crds course after all.

reviews.author: YUENSC
reviews.title: Hard course
reviews.comment_content:
A basic introduction of signal processing (point to point) and internet hierarchy

Have you ever wondered what technologies go into your mobile phone or a WiFi hotspot? Through hands on work with a simple but fully functional wireless communication system, you will understand the basic engineering tools used and tradeoffs encountered in the design of these systems. This course is centered on weekly laboratories, each designed to introduce an important concept in the design of these systems. The lab sessions are supported by two one-hour lectures and a tutorial that introduce the concepts for the next laboratory, as well as reviewing and expanding the concepts learned in the previous laboratory.
reviews.comment_teaching: Clear but not that interesting, always asking for question from students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good enough.

HW1: 14.4/20
HW2: 89.5/100
HW3: 78.5/100
lab: 20.83/25
MT: 49/50    Ave: 37.5/50            SD: 7.8
Final: 94.5 /100 Ave: 74.8/100    SD: 18.1

Please refer to other post for the distribution
I forgot.

Letter grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Some hw, lab per week,
lab require some programming and understanding of recent lectures., not straightforward

Final is great  as a lot of stuff I memorized is given in the paper.
All long questions.

reviews.title: Elec 1200
reviews.comment_content:
The content is mainly divided into three parts.
There is homework after each topic which consists of a few questions regarding the taught topic. The homework is included in the final grade.
There are no attendance requirement for the lectures but for the lab sessions you can not be absent for more the 2?(not sure) sessions or you will fail the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is extremely good at explaining the content. Even without any prior knowledge, you are able to score high marks.

The teaching is divided into mainly two parts. The professor gives the lectures and there are additional lab sessions which you have to use MATLAB to complete the lab work.
reviews.comment_grading: You need a bit of time to get used to the grading because a lot of people score high grades on the midterms and finals. Even with high midterm and final grades, you are not guaranteed a high overall grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
There is not a lot of workload in terms of homework or assessments. There are three assessments after each big topics which you have to hand in online. Other than that there are only midterms and finals.
The completion of the lab sessions and the post lab quizzes are also graded. The labwork is somewhat difficult for people who are new to MATLAB and it take a bit of time to get used to all the functions. Although you are given three hours to complete the lab, previewing the content before the lab sessions is extremely helpful and will make it possible for you to finish early.
There are mandatory lab quizzes after each lab which is also counted towards your grade. The quizzes are not that difficult since it is purely based on the lab work done on that day.

reviews.author: 陈润洲
reviews.comment_content: The stuffs in course are generally related to life and 啊are useful. Contents are neither too simple nor difficult to understand. You can learn a lot about communication in ELEC 1200.
reviews.comment_teaching: Ross taught well in general, he will leave around 5 mins for Q&A in each course though sometimes no one ask him. But for some particular parts which we are not familiar with, he might not explain in detail all the time and you should spend some time on them after class.
reviews.comment_grading: It's not difficult to get an A but if you want a plus, then do work really hard.
reviews.comment_workload: The largest workload course I had this semester but it's a 4 credits course so that makes sense. You should spend several hours on the materials and labs quiz course aside the courses. There will be 3 homework.

reviews.author: Brian123
reviews.comment_content: signal transfer, Network
reviews.comment_teaching:
上堂有D悶, Lecturer 幾有心機教, 你肯問佢肯答, 講簡單英文, 不過有時成日指住個screen 去this this this, 如果岩岩瞓醒, 要follow返佢進度都有D難, 語調有D單一, 令到我上堂有時會瞓著

Tutorial 係lab 既introduction, 有PRS, 唔知係咪計attendence
reviews.comment_grading:
ok既
我mid-term, exam below mean都有C+
reviews.comment_workload:
4份assignment, 每星期一個lab, assignments 同 lab 有source跟住做其實唔難, 有某D topic我都覺幾有趣
完lab會有online short quiz

reviews.author: butter New fly
reviews.title: Good course
reviews.comment_content: This course is about basic communication system, with first 2/3 of the course focusing on precise communication between two points and last 1/3 on communication networks. Last 1/3 requires some memorization.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Murch is very passionate and explains things in a clear way and uploads class video in time on canvas. He also constantly encourages us to answer questions. But since it's 9:30am class, sometimes I'm a bit sleepy. The TAs Allie and Cupid are very helpful and friendly during lab sessions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading policy:
Lab check-off points      10%
post lab interview           15%
Homework(three in total) 10%
Midterm                           25%
Final                                 40%

Everyone could get similar points for lab ranging from 22%-24%. Midterm has many questions the same as pastpaper and was very easy, some statistics: total=82; mean=64.3; SD=13.9. Final has some tricky questions, but overall it's also easy, some statistics: total=100, mean=64.91, SD= 20.12.
To be honest, if you understand all the homework and sample questions, midterm and final shouldn't be a problem. I got 95.5% and an A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is the only thing that is not very perfect about this course. There are 10 labs in total, and each lab requires at least an hour beforehand to look over the lab manual.Many of the labs use matlab which is not very easy at the beginning. But matlab is very useful. Homeworks can be a bit tricky as well.

reviews.author: tisb1234
reviews.comment_content: The amount of content is not that big. There are a lot of chapters in this course, however as this is 1000 level course, the course does not go so into complex concepts. You can basically learn a lot of creative things.
reviews.comment_teaching: The way professor tries to teach is pretty good. He tries to relate all the concepts to real life problems so that students could easily understand. However, after the mid-term as content got little bit difficult, I had tough time understanding the concept. I had to watch youtube videos to understand clearly.
reviews.comment_grading: I think grading is decent. I got 98/100 in mid term. For final, I got low 80s - I think it was around 1.5 sd above. I got nearly full marks in homeworks(10% in total), average 9 in pre-lab(10%) and okok in post lab interviews (which accounts for 10%). I got an A+ in the end.
reviews.comment_workload: I think workload for this course is too much. There are labs every week and you need to prepare post-lab interviews while finishing and submitting pre-labs every week. I took 1~1.5 hour finishing pre-lab (sometimes 30 minutes). For 4 credit course and comparing other 4 credit elec courses, I think workload is quite heavy.

reviews.author: cheung
reviews.title: nice course to start communication technology
reviews.comment_content: a lot of different areas like Internet layers and MATLAB information transfer. it is based on the same introduction course of ELEC in MIT, so the content is good and well organised.
reviews.comment_teaching: OK but the instructor encourage students to seat in the front and he seldom uses microphone. after midterm, the content became more and he always run out of time at around 3-5 minutes which is acceptable.
reviews.comment_grading: it is ok and the A range is slight larger than average in UST, even not full mark in post-lab interview but 1SD higher in midterm and final can get good grade. 2SD is able to get A or A+
reviews.comment_workload: as a introduction course in ECE, not a lot to calculate but a lot to remember, so we need to remember things particularly after midterm, workload is slightly higher than MATH course.

reviews.author: nangyo
reviews.comment_content: Introductory course for communication system. Starting with understanding of bit sequence, this course analyses aspects of different communication levels.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very interesting, clear, and focused.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grading. Midterms and finals are basically the most important factor deciding the grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Work load for this course is s pretty large for 1st year student. Especially, lab materials including pre labs consumes time way more than expected. For a student who have little knowledge on coding might be difficult to work on MATLAB. There are three homework assignments as well, which are not too difficult.

reviews.author: mike suen
reviews.comment_content: elec對signaling的入門course. 難道並不大. lecture的ppt中的內容十分顯淺易明. lab的進度和教學內容同步並需要有對ppt的良好理解. 總括而言是一門好grade科
reviews.comment_teaching: 基本上堂上也大多照ppt講, 但不會太沉悶, 上上堂也無妨.
reviews.comment_grading: 因為比較容易, mean比較高.
reviews.comment_workload: workload並不大, 大約每個禮拜1個lab. homework就只有3份. 需要比較用心去做pre-lab, 因為prelab都計分既.

reviews.author: lcs
reviews.title: Nice course
reviews.comment_content: This course mainly talk about the communication in computer network. It will focus on five of the seven layers of the OSI model. The lab on each week focus on the knowledge you learn on previous week and will definitely help your understanding. There would be a post-lab interview which would ask you about the things you just done in the lab, so make sure you know what you are doing in the lab rather than just following the instructions without thinking. Tutorial covers the upcoming lab and the pre-lab exercise, so register a time slot that is before the lab session. If you are confident enough, you could skip the tutorial and read the lab manual and ppt on your own.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. SHI is very good at teaching. He has a nice accent and his in-depth explanation makes no difficulty in understanding. He is also very nice and willing to answer most of the questions. The lecture notes are good in general except the comic sans...
But many of the TAs have bad pronunciation and sometimes difficult to understand, so be careful when choosing TA to do the post-lab interview.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is good
mid-term +1SD
final +0.5SD
homework 7.5/10 10/10 9.5/10
pre-lab, lab, post-lab interview almost all full mark and I got A-
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is somehow heavier than other courses since you have to attend the lab every week and do the pre-lab exercises. There are only three homeworks throughout the semester and it is quite simple. The pre-lab exercises are easy also but sometimes it could be time-consuming. You could get full mark with ease on pre-lab and homework. Mid-term and final are similar to that of other courses, nothing special.

reviews.author: Edwardtpl
reviews.title: Good course to learn the basic
reviews.comment_content:
50% calculation
50% data content
not very hard calculation just simple
need to memorize the content

normal, not too bored
murch quite nice
willing answer question

infinite B range

midterm quite easy
