reviews.author: manselrian
reviews.title: Informative course
reviews.comment_content: Interesting introduction to signal transmission.  It covers difficulties in wirless communication, baisic signal processing, error correction, data transfer methods, protocols, layers, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professors and TAs are fluent in English, nice and helpful in answering enquires.  Lecture notes, tutorial notes and lab manuals are well prepared and informative.  This course has the best  teaching in my opinion.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is good from what I know.  
Midterm+prelab nearly full marks
Missed one homework
Lab full marks
Final +0.5SD --> A
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework+Prelab+Lab+Post lab interview+Midterm+Final,
2 hrs lecture
1 hr tutorial
3 hr lab
6 hrs per week in total.
Workload is a bit much for a 4 credit course.

reviews.author: sgargaa
reviews.title: Fun and interesting
reviews.comment_content: The content is pretty interesting and gives a great amount of information on various topics basically covering everything about the transmission, communication and reception of a signal.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is great and he takes initiative to meet you after class and often comes to the labs just to inquire about your course progress and actively asks for feedback on his teaching, and about the course. He has a great accent and I personally loved the way he taught in class. Even if you meet him outside the class, in the corridor, he would greet you if he remembers your face from the class. Even the TA, Cupid Chow, was pretty cheerful, and the notes that she prepared were pretty great. You will not mind going to classes for this reason. Apart from that, both, the lectures and tutorials are only 50 minutes long. Hence, it should not be a problem.
reviews.comment_grading:
Prelab exercises 10% and these have to be handed in at the start of the lab every week.
Lab Check-off Points 5% that is what you do during the labs. This makes attendance during class necessary.
Post-lab interview 10% which is a mini interview at the end of each lab, and you need to be thorough with the course notes and lab answers for this. The marking here is pretty lenient though.
Each lab group must have 2 students which you usually declare by the end of the second week. Please make sure your partner is hard-working.
Homework (3 of them) 10%
Midterm exam 25%
Final exam 40%
reviews.comment_workload: I personally believe that you should take this course only if it is compulsory for your major requirements. Do not take this course unnecessarily as the amount of workload for this course is pretty high, with regular submissions of assignments and prelabs. There is a bit of cramming work that is required towards the end of the course, so I would suggest you start studying a few days in advance.

reviews.author: ayymiami
reviews.title: Decent introduction signals course
reviews.comment_content: Basic wireless communication theory, signal processing and error correction in the first half of the course, and the second half covering internet protocols and data transfer methodologies. This course feels like the first step before taking ELEC2100.
reviews.comment_teaching: Both the professors have very fluent English and teach well, but the course easily gets boring when there is no interactivity between lecturer and students. More than a few times, the professor would ask simple questions in class but no student would bother answering even if they knew the answers, making it clearly frustrating for the professors and even less interesting for the class.
reviews.comment_grading: This course requires you to learn many new concepts and once you are able to get acquainted with them, it becomes easy to do well. This is clearly one of those courses where the more you study, the higher marks you will probably get. The problem is that if you're not one to study much, you will be left far behind.
reviews.comment_workload: Each week you need to complete 1-2 pages worth of pre-lab assignment that often includes MATLAB scripting and plotting graphs. Since most students can't afford to have it on their personal computers, you're forced to work at the barn or library. Labs are conducted in pairs but these are to be done separately. There are also post-lab interviews where the TAs ask you questions based on the lab tasks(which are often hard to understand). Apart from this there were also a couple of written assignments  that take a few hours to complete at the very least. I suggest having some friends also in the class and discuss material with each other often

reviews.author: CC
reviews.title: A lot to learn
reviews.comment_content: Covers basic ideas of communication systems. Some of them are quite in-depth and challenging. The topics range from software to hardware. It uses MATLAB for coding.
reviews.comment_teaching: This A is definitely for Yimeng. She is amazing. She replies email very promptly. She explains things clearly and patiently. She is also very organized and responsible. Thumbs up!
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework
a combination of maths and logic

Lab
pre-lab + lab tasks + post lab interview
2 students in a group to do about 5 tasks every lab.
for post-lab interview, the TAs would ask you question about the theory behind the lab tasks. I just threw anything I remember from the lectures at them, which sometimes work.

Exam
Mid-term + Final
a MUCH harder version of homework questions

All the hard work pays off. This course gives good grades!
reviews.comment_workload:
All basic MATLAB functions are taught in the first lab session. There is quite a lot to take in for the first few labs. For slow learners like me, it was a lot to take in for EVERY week.
Pre-lab, lab tasks and post-lab interview are all required. One of the later pre-lab took me so long that I almost gave up.
There is a LOT to do every week.

reviews.author: Aarav
reviews.title: Would Recommend It (A very straightforward course)
reviews.comment_content: The content was very simple, straightforward, and not very big. It mostly taught the basics of communication and bits streaming to provide students with a fundamental understanding of the above.
reviews.comment_teaching: While many courses in HKUST have satisfactory teaching, this course does not fall under that case. Professor Shi is an excellent professor who can proficiently answer student's queries along with Assistant Professor Chow who always went out of her way to ensure everyone understood the concept and was always willing to meet students outside classes to help them.
reviews.comment_grading:
The Grading was very lenient, with both exams being pretty easy. This semester the top 30 percentile got an A range.

I was mean in the Midterm exam and upper quartile in finals while the lab's post-quiz were roughly 8.7/10 and lab checks were 5/5, the project was 17/20 and full in all HWs. My overall grade was A- (don't worry, everything was easy, just required a decent amount of work in)
reviews.comment_workload:
The Workload was adequate with lab every week (except for a few). Although the official time for labs was 3 hours, most students were able to complete them in half the time.

HWs were not time-consuming and mostly straightforward with some tricky parts.

There were 2 classes every week but attendance was not mandatory (Although I recommend going to classes, especially after midterm).

reviews.author: AuTomatocTi
reviews.title: good course but cover too few things in our semester
reviews.comment_content:
**This course has mainly focused on how the signal transmitted from one device to another and mainly divided into 2 parts: the character of a channel play, and how the sender(receiver) needs to do to overcome the limit of the channel

(details):
Lecture:
- discrete-time waveforms & sampling
-# bit rate & SPB
-# unit step function
-# effect of channel(attenuation,delay,offset &blurring)
- introduction of the concept of communication channel and LTI system
-# exponential step response model
- training sequence & framing
- Intersymbol interference (ISI), settling time, eye diagram
-# equalizer & recursive model

-# BER and noise(AWGN)
-# Gaussian PDF & Q-function
-# transmit power,threshold, signal-to-noise ratio(SNR)
-# coding & decoding of error correction code(ECE)
- code rate, gross bitrate, net bitrate
- Hamming distance, error-correction & detection ability of an ECE
- repetition code, (8,4,3) code, (9,4,4) code

- sinusoidal/frequency response model of signals (continuous time & discrete time)
-# Fourier series(transform) & amplitude spectrum
-# filter
- spectrogram, quantization bits
- auditory coding(psycho-acoustics, masking effects, non-uniform quantization)
- compression (lossless, lossy)
- data rate

-# frequency division multiplexing & demultiplexing
- transmission bandwidth
- analog modulation(circuit-switching) & digital modulation(packet-switching)

-Internet layer
- 5 laying of the internet (application, transport, network, datalink, physical)
- (datalink layer)MAC address, TDMA, FDMA, #slotted ALOHA
- (network layer)routing &forwarding, #Dijkstra's algorithm, IP address & sub-mask of IP
- (transport layer) throughput, #TCP
-(application layer) client-sever & P2P structure, HTTP, DNS

#exam mainly focuses on

Lab:
    >lab1: Introduction to MATLAB
    >lab2: Characterizing and modelling a channel
    >lab3: Communication protocol and BER
    >lab4: Eye diagram and equalization
    >lab5: Bit errors and SNR
    >lab6: Time-frequency analysis
    >lab7: Frequency division multiplexing


Project:
*- aim: minimize the energy per bit of signal transmission in a channel with unknown properties
   > mat lab code: encoding, decoding, and basic setting(threshold e.t.c)
  > report: 1000 words
**projects in a different semester can have large difference

*some concept that may covered(but didn't covered in our semester):
- Q/I modulation
- BPSK/ QPSK
- constellation diagram
- Huffman encoding compression
- Hamming code(7,4,3)
- Brust error
reviews.comment_teaching:
professor and IA(Cupid CHOW) will ans your question and mark the paper quickly
also, I like how he uses marks in Canvas to represent seat no in the exam
reviews.comment_grading:
quite a good grading
as most of the marks can easily get
*(it is not difficult to get ~80% marks in midterm and final if you had studied and didn't miss the lectures)
*(try do the hw and project together with your friends for double check to reduce careless mistakes, getting full marks in hw is not difficult at all)

my grade:
assignment(10%)
Hw1:30/30
Hw2:30/30
Hw3:30/30

lab check-off(5%): 24/24
post-lab quiz(10%): 22/24
*1st lab doesn't count
*pots-lab quiz is accessible after completing all check-off point, each quiz have 5 min to complete 4 questions

project(20%)
project code: 4/4 *(can get all 4 marks if your code can run properly)
project result: 6/6 *(depends on your result of the code)
project report: 7/10

midterm(25%): 35.5/40
final(30%): 49/50

grade: 92.75/100(A+)
*cutoff: around 91% can get A+
>85% probably can get A-range
reviews.comment_workload:
not too heavy workload:
- 3 assignment
    - each has 3 questions
- lab
    - lab check-off (4 per lab)
    - lab quiz (4 questions per lab)
- project
   - Matlab code
   - report(max 1000 words)

reviews.author: Zhijie
reviews.title: A System View of Communications: from Signals to Packets
reviews.comment_content:
Examine a voice communication system to identify the practical context of key theoretical concepts in ECE.
Identify typical problems and tradeoffs encountered in electronic and computer engineering systems.
Analyze simple approaches to address a range of problems and tradeoffs.
Use software tools, such as MATLAB, to investigate potential solutions to problems and tradeoffs in order to validate an analysis, and to handle cases not amenable to simple analysis.
Work in a cooperative setting on real hardware or by simulations where the simplifying assumptions used in theoretical analysis may be violated, and assess the benefits and limitations of such analysis.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Ross speaks English very clearly, like the voice actor of some documentary films. And he is very patient, always willing to answer any question. The content is useful too.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab Check-off Points(15%)
Post-lab quiz
Five minutes quiz. No lab report is required.
(15%)

Homework
Submit online
10%

Midterm Exam
Time: 20:00 - 20:50
30%

Final Project
30%
reviews.comment_workload: not very much compared to other 4 credits courses. The project doesn't involve any Fourier transform so it's relatively easy. each homework can be done within an hour if you are familiar with the content. The lab quiz can be a little annoying but still acceptable, and the lab check is given to you if you finish the Matlab code. A lot of people just preview the material and leave the lab within 15 minutes.

reviews.author: FrostyP4nc4kes
reviews.title: If online, avoid at all costs.
reviews.comment_content:
we spend 11/24 lectures on the basics of sending bits through a channel, looking at a received output, doing some equalising, and dealing with noise, which is very annoying. You have to draw two triangles, trapezoids, and rectangles, find where they intersect, and then find the area of the shared region. It's easy, but my goodness, it takes a long time, and it is very easy for you to choke under pressure.

the rest of the lectures were
- error correcting codes,
- frequency domain (fourier transform and series) <- i really enjoyed this because we used eulers identity to make life easier
- Last part of the course was networks, and all the layers in a communication network.

The last part is very interesting but very very fact-heavy, and memorisation heavy. Also my prof kinda just didn't really explain everything that well so I had to google a lot.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Zhang was a decent enough teacher for the most part. But i wouldn't count on being able to ask him to explain things. It was so frustrating trying to understand hamming distance. which was actually so very easy, but he just couldn't explain it in a way that would make sense.

The good news is you have Cupid. She is life saver. She will explain hard concepts for you :) also she will give you hw help :)
reviews.comment_grading:
Trash. I hate the way that the exams were done, and how things were graded.

The HW is graded, so do your best: 10%

Midterm 25%:
online format ruined the exam. YOU COULDNT GO BACK AND FORTH ON MCQ. so yeah either you get yourself together and do the question immediately, or you die.
ALSO for the FRQ, it was so frustrating not being able to go back and forth, because i made a few mistakes and realised too late and couldn't go back. On the next question i spent 5 minutes doing the question and 10 minutes being salty that i couldn't fix the previous question:

MEAN: 25.78/36 idk sd
Me: 26.5

Final: same as midterm basically... not fun at all. 30%
Mean: 31.3 SD:9.4
Me: 39.5

Project: They basically compare the results of your code to the results of a code that the teachers do.... but like the teachers are literal pros at this so it's quite unfair. 20%

Mean: 10.6/20 SD: 4.5
Me: 13

Labs: so so so so so annoying. You have to do a post lab quiz: 5 minutes, 5 questions(they like trick questions, and they like algebraically annoying questions >:( )
i got above mean for 4 of them, and below mean for 2 of them. 15%, (5% completion, 10% annoying post lab quiz)

In the end, got a B+


TLDR: better grade if in person :)
reviews.comment_workload:
I think I'll count labs in this part because well... 4 hours a week on labs that require you to use a degenerate software known as matlab. don't get me wrong, matlab is useful and very cool... when it works. But my goodness me it is so frustrating to code in matlab.

The HW is doable, i usually can do it all in the last day. But NOT the last minute.

for some reason, we were also forced to do both a final project AND a final exam. So yeah that was a lot of work. >:(

reviews.author: ricecrackie
reviews.title: so far so bad
reviews.comment_content:
Refer to others' reviews for the syllabus.
So far, I found various things in this course fucked up. I hope it's not only me facing these problems.
First of all, the inconsistency of lab quizzes site on canvas. They separated lecture and lab as two courses on canvas. The post-lab quiz for lab1 is posted on lecture course while the subsequent labs quizzes are posted on lab course. I lost about 3 minutes for my lab2 post-lab quiz to look for the quiz.
Secondly, the post-lab quiz has very little correlation with the lab. Finishing the lab is not enough for you to get full marks in the quiz. You need to be really familiar with matlab and course content to get a good score.
Now HW1 is asking us to draw graphs of step responses without any hints on how to implement them in matlab. The lab is just  a joke. It provides very little help on training matlab skills.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is not bad.
Prof Shi and Cupid tried their best to explain the materials. Both of them speak very clearly and are very helpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab 15% (checkpoints 5% + 5 minutes post-lab quiz 10%)
Homework 10%
midterm 25%
project 20%
final exam 30%
reviews.comment_workload: If you are only aiming a passing grade, it's low. All you have to do is remember to finish the post-lab quiz for attendance and submit something for assignments and project.

reviews.author: Spade
reviews.comment_content:
Have you ever wondered what technologies go into your 5G mobile phone. an Internet of Things (IoT) network or a WiFi hotspot? Through hands on work with a simple but fully functional wireless communication system, you will understand the basic engineering tools used and tradeoffs encountered in the design of these systems.  This course is centered on weekly laboratories, each designed to introduce an important concept in the design of these systems. The lab sessions are supported by two one hour lectures and a tutorial that introduces the concepts for the next laboratory, as well as reviewing and expanding the concepts learned in the previous laboratory.

Co-requisite(s): (COMP 1021 OR COMP 1022P) AND (MATH 1003 OR MATH 1014 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH 1024)
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Letaief is very kind, wiling to listen students'questions and  help students. His course won't make you feel hard to follow, and it's not boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab 30%
   Lab Check-off Points (15%)
   Post-lab quiz(Five minutes quiz. No lab report is required.)(15%)
Homework(Submit online) 10%
Midterm Exam (It covers the course material (L01 - L13)) 30%
Final Project 30%

My example grading:
Although I'm bad at project, with good performance in homework and Midterm, I still get A in this course.

Lab
   Lab Check-off Points : 28/28
   Post-lab quiz(Five minutes quiz. No lab report is required.):
   29.33/35
Homework(Submit online) 10%:  Can't find my grade on canvas, but remember it's higher than average about 10-20 scorses.
Midterm Exam (It covers the course material (L01 - L13)):
34/40 (Ave:26.64, High:35)
Final Project: 22/30(Ave:21.75)
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very low, only 3 homework and one project to finish. And have 7 labs.

reviews.author: Sirius981
reviews.comment_content:
You need to watch the lecture video before attending the class, which you need to put a lot of time into this subject.

Suggest finish the lab before the lab session since the lab is quite challenging and the lab session time only has one hour, so you don't have enough time to finish if you start doing the lab in the lab session.
reviews.comment_teaching: The TA is good and very helpful. The lecture is just doing an in-class quiz and explain the question.
reviews.comment_grading: Grade: B-
reviews.comment_workload: Very heavy workload. You have to watch the lecture video before class and do the in-class quiz. 4 assignments in total. In-class quiz every lecture. This subject needs a mid-term exam and final exam.

reviews.author: Alex Du
reviews.title: A good course
reviews.comment_content:
Content is stated in many of the former reviews. If you would like to see a full list, please go and find them in 2019 reviews, since they are mostly the same.
The course introduces basic concepts of electronics and signal processing. It is very well designed. If you take a look at MIT 6.002, you will find that they are delivered with similar content & material, while ELEC 1200 is less complicated.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Murch is himself an expert in the field. In 2018, his paper were the global top 10 cited in the field of communication. But for the questions which bothered me a lot but definitely seems very obvious to him, he would do quite a lot to help me understand. In addition to question answering, his lectures are also good and steady, with every content well explained and well demonstrated.

Cupid CHOW is the very best IA. She responses to emails very quickly and she is a very nice person. She does not get mad or irrigated even though one may ask the same question again and again. She even answers to my asking things like "I got bad in post lab quizzes, could you give me some advice?" Also, a cute thing is she apologizes when marks are deducted from my homework hahaha...
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is good. I can give you the following statistics.

10% homework. I got 9.5/10. Mean approximately 7.8/10.
30% lab, I got 26.5/30, while he mean is approximately 22/30.
30% midterm, I got 27/30, while the mean is 21/30. High 1.2 sd.
30% final project, I got 29/30, while the mean is 20/30. High 2 sd.

Total 92%, and finally got an A+. The A range is really wide for this course. In fact I never expected an A+, as I thought an A is already fair. But, well, things are beyond my expectation.
reviews.comment_workload:
I would say workload is appropriate for a 4 credit course.
The homework have traps inside, so if you do not work with an equally hardworking friend, it is hard to get full marks. You have to study and review every week in order to deal with the post lab quizzes.  The labs are not hard, but if you do not treat them seriously, your final project would be doomed.
Please be very aware of the post lab quizzes. They are EXTREMELY hard to handle. 5 questions in 5 minutes, and no previewing before submission of one question and no reviewing after submission of one question, so basically you must work out the math very quickly and memorize the concepts very well. I got many 3/5 in post lab quizzes.
Final project is individual work, and answers are different so you cannot help each other. Half of it is not challenging, while the other half is quite difficult. You must start early and work hard to attain a high mark in final project.

reviews.author: BrownBoi17
reviews.title: Amazing Course for those interested in Communications
reviews.comment_content:
L01: Course Introduction
Metrics for communication systems, the digital abstraction, basic recipes for transmitting information

L02: Signals
Point-to-Point Digital Links, discrete time waveform

L03: Real World Channels
Representing discrete time bit waveforms, effects of the channel

L04: Linear Time Invariant Systems
Exponential Step Response

L05: Transmitting Data
Communication protocols, decoding bits, asynchronous serial communication

L06: Inter-symbol Interference and Eye Diagram

L07: Feedback Model of the Channel

L08: Channel Equalization

L09: Noise
Noise, power, binary channel model, BER of the binary channel

L10: Noise
Modeling noise, Gaussian PDF, BER of AWGN channel

L11: Error Correcting Codes
Hamming distance, (n,k) block codes, error detection vs. correction, repetition codes, (8,4) codes

L12:  Error Correcting Codes
(n,k,d) Block codes, (9,4,4) block codes.

L13: The Frequency Domain
Representing signals as sums of sinusoids, Euler’s identity

L14: Discrete Fourier Transform/Frequency Response

L15: Lossless & Lossy Source Coding

L16: Signal Transmission – Modulation

L17: Signal Transmission – Demodulation

L18: I-Q Modulation

L19: Introduction to Networks

L20: Link Layer

L21: Network and Transport Layers

L22: Transport and Application Layers

L23: Course Review
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Letaief was my lecturer for the first few weeks but unfortunately due to some illness was unable to teach the remaining lectures. He is enthusiastic about the content and always entertains doubts during lectures to clear concepts. There is no way you can walk away from his lectures without grasping the basic concepts.
Prof. Murch taught the remaining lectures and also made the lectures very interesting - by relating the course content to real life situations. This also reinforced the concepts.
Cupid Chow was the TA for the entire course and handled all the lab assignments. She also cleared all doubts during the lectures. She is very responsive and takes the time to help you out.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading weightage:
Homework - 10%
Lab - 30%
       - Checkpoints - 15%
       - Post-lab quiz - 15%
Midterm - 30%
Final Project - 30%
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not too much for a 4 point course but still includes includes Weekly Labs, Homework Assignments and a Final Project.

reviews.comment_content:

reviews.author: Ho Ka Ying
reviews.title: Very informative, Great Course!
reviews.comment_content:
About communication system. It answers almost all questions about communication system, explains it from scratch. Really recommend it if you are curious of how internet or telephone works, even if you are not an ELEC student.  

The design of course and lab are great. You will end up learning a lot!

Useful and informative.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Murch is a great professor. He can explain things well, and interact with us. It is comfortable to ask questions even in the midst of his lecture (no one feels strange about that), and ask thousands of questions after lecture. He is very friendly and experienced, and seems like understanding what we do not understand. That's why we like asking him as he really can answer. And he always smiles.

Our TA Cupid is great as well! Very cheerful and helpful! She has office hour especially before exam.
reviews.comment_grading: Good grade as long as you understand the concepts.
reviews.comment_workload:
OK workload. As long as you follow the lecture and lab well, and understand the stuff, with some practice (review of past paper), you will be prepared for the exams.

There are 3-4 assignments, mid term and final.

reviews.comment_content: It's just an intro-course. There wouldn't be anything quite useful, to be honest. But it would be quite useful to understand what you are going to learn in the next few years if you want to take signaling stream in ELEC courses.

reviews.comment_content:
- Basic bits and communication
- Noise
- Modulation and demodulation
- I/Q modulation
- Networking
- Layering
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor was good as he tried to allow as many questions to be asked as possible. his languages were generally all clear and his ppt slides were clear. Various calculation methods were instructed step b step and therefore I was able to follow the step and build my understanding
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is quite ok
There are mainly 4 sections that are graded :
1st : Lab -  Mainly determined on whether you were able to complete the 5 tasks that are given and also the post-lab quiz at the end of the session. The post-lab quiz is not that hard but needs some amount of concentration in able to score over 4
2nd : Homework -  3 homework are given and it is not hard to score high scores. It is basically a general review of over the 8~9 lectures that was taught
3rd : Midterm - Is about the first 8~9lectures taught and is not hard to get over mean however it is essential to have deep understanding of the calculation concepts
4th : Final - Is about the whole course and is quite hard. It deals with various topics and it is essential for students to remember some important facts. Calculation part is quite decent.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is reasonable. Every week you have to go to a lab and complete approximately 4~5 tasks based on the things we have learnt last week. It is basically just MATLAB coding which is generally explained during your tutorials, therefore, it is important to attend tutorials and understand the concept.

There are mainly 3 homework to do every 8~9 lectures which is basically a summary of all the concepts. It is not that hard and therefore students would be able to finish the homework with not much dificulty and not spending much time on it.

reviews.author: Dog23
reviews.comment_content:
Elec 1200 consists of three main parts.
Signal errors, how a signal or a message is transmitted, and layers in networking.
Most of the content is easy to follow and can be understood without any knowledge related.
reviews.comment_teaching: It's quite good. Involved examples using MATLAB to demonstrate the topics during lectures, making it easier to follow. The lecturer tried various methods other than just reading the lecture pages for easier understanding. And there are video lectures.
reviews.comment_grading: quite reasonable. Revision pays off.
reviews.comment_workload:
There's a lab every week but the tutorial usually covers a lot of information about the labs, making it easy to handle. But there's a short quiz after each lab, but it's easy as it is open book. It'll be better if you're familiar with the topic.
For homework, there's 3 in total, one for each section.

reviews.author: ptrknow
reviews.title: An Okay Course
reviews.comment_content:
Refer to other comments for details of course contents.
Whether or not the contents are interesting mainly depends on yourself.
I would say the contents fit me well. Some parts of the contents (like IQ modulation, coding) are really intriguing.
Basically, this course covers a lot of ground of many engineering principles, introducing their conceptual intuition, application of maths, and handling of tradeoffs.
reviews.comment_teaching:
MURCH, Ross:
+ intuitive explanation on many concepts
+ providing other subtle details related to the concepts (not written in notes, nor tested in the exam), which are fun to hear
+ standard English, easy to hear and understand
+ passionate, always encouraging us to raise questions (and able to answer questions clearly and with details)

- His explanation on mathematics is not detailed enough. This isn't a big problem. In case you really don't understand, just ask him for more details.

SHI, Bertram Emil (edX video):
+ Very detailed and "vivid" explanations
+ Because you are watching video, you can control the pace on your own
+ understandable English

+/- Talking quite speedily. For me, I really need the subtitle when watching his video.
reviews.comment_grading:
Should be okay. Here's the reference:

Lab (25%): Mean 19.9 / 25 (High:23 Low: 12.8)
Homework (10%): Mean ~7.56 / 10
Midterm (25%): Mean 79.6/100 SD 16.9
Final (40%): Mean 84.2/120 SD 23.52

My data
Lab: 22.67/25
Homework: 9/10
Midterm: 91/100
Final: 105/120
Overall: ~89%
Grade: A

Labs:
There is a post-lab quiz every week, constituting 15% of the overall grade (another 10% is basically your completion of the lab).
Some (small parts) of the quizzes are tricky and difficult, really requiring you to have a full understanding of what you are doing in the lab (and what the lecture is talking about).
Out of 45 question in total (each quiz has 5 questions), I get 38 right.

Homeworks:
Most questions are new. Don't expect the source can help you much (do help a little bit though).
Questions can be tricky (one or two of them may be difficult).
Think twice about each question!

Exams:
Basically easier than homework and review questions.
Make sure you are familiar with and understand the homework and the review questions. Doing this, you should have no big problem in the exam. (Also be careful !)
For the final exam, you need to memorize key points from the notes as well (mostly for the network part). The final exam is just a memory contest, with guidings to help you recall.
reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly labs (10 in total, the first one can be skipped)
3 Homeworks
Midterm and Final

Workload should be moderate (because labs are greatly simplified! Unlike before, there are no prelab questions and postlab interviews. Lab tasks are also not tedious, although requiring you to think a lot.)
A hint for you: try to prepare every lab beforehand. You can then probably leave the lab very early. Attending tutorials is not really necessary (I skip all of them lol).

As for the exams -
There is quite much stuff to remember: formulas (first two parts of the course) and points (third part of the course, many advantages, disadvantages, why doing this, why doing that, why not brabrabra). Note that the third part also has formulas (we need to derive those formulas again in the final exam, which is already done in the lecture notes!).
But memorizing is not really difficult, as long as you pay attention to the lectures beforehand.

reviews.comment_workload:
Packets
Have you ever wondered what technologies go into your mobile phone or a WiFi hotspot? Through hands on work with a simple but fully functional wireless communication system, you will understand the basic engineering tools used and tradeoffs encountered in the design of these systems. This course is centered on weekly laboratories, each designed to introduce an important concept in the design of these systems. The lab sessions are supported by two one-hour lectures and a tutorial that introduce the concepts for the next laboratory, as well as reviewing and expanding the concepts learned in the previous laboratory.
